chunk_0.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 1: 1.1 Dhritarashtra said  What did my people and the sons of Pandu do when they had assembled
together eager for battle on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya. Chapter 1, Verse 2: 1.2. Sanjaya said  Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle-array,
King Duryodhana then approached his teacher (Drona) and spoke these words. Chapter 1, Verse 3: 1.3. "Behold, O Teacher! this mighty army of the sons of Pandu,
arrayed by the son of Drupada, thy wise disciple. Chapter 1, Verse 4: 1.4. Here are heroes, mighty archers, eal in battle to Bhima
and Arjuna, Yoyudhana (Satyaki), Virata and Drupada, of the great car (mighty
warriors). Chapter 1, Verse 5: 1.5. "Dhrishtaketu, chekitana and the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit
and Kuntibhoja and Saibya, the best men.
chunk_0.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 0

chunk_1.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 6: 1.6. "The strong Yodhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son
of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of
Draupadi, all of great chariots (great heroes). Chapter 1, Verse 7: 1.7. "Know also, O best among the twice-born! the names of those
who are the most distinguished amongst ourselves, the leaders of my army;
these I name to thee for thy information. Chapter 1, Verse 8: 1.8. "Thyself and Bhishma, and Karna and also Kripa, the victorious
in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and also Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta. Chapter 1, Verse 9: 1.9. "And also many other heroes who are ready to give up their
lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled
in battle.
chunk_1.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 1

chunk_2.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 10: 1.10. "This army of ours marshalled by Bhishma is insufficient,
whereas that army of theirs marshelled by Bhima is sufficient. Chapter 1, Verse 11: 1.11. "Therefore do ye all, stationed in your respective positions,
in the several divisions of the army, protect Bhishma alone." Chapter 1, Verse 12: 1.12. His glorious grandsire (Bhishma), the oldest of the Kauravas,
in order to cheer Duryodhana, now roared like a lion, and blew his conch. Chapter 1, Verse 13: 1.13. Then (following Bhishma), conches and kettledrums, tabors,
drums and cow horns blared forth ite suddenly (from the Kaurava side)
and the sound was tremendous. Chapter 1, Verse 14: 1.14. Then, also, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna),
seated in the magnificent chariot, yoked with white horses, blew divine
conches.
chunk_2.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 2

chunk_3.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 15: 1.15. Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya and Arjuna blew the Devadatta
and Bhima (the wolf-bellied), the doer of terrible deeds, blew the great
conch Paundra. Chapter 1, Verse 16: 1.16. The king Yodhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya;
Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and the Manipushpaka. Chapter 1, Verse 17: 1.17. The king of Kasi, an exellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty
car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna and Virata and Satyaki, the unconered. Chapter 1, Verse 18: 1.18. Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, O Lord of the earth, and
the son of Subhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conches separately. Chapter 1, Verse 19: 1.19. That tumultuous sound rent the hearts of (the members of)
Dhritarashtra's party, making both the heaven and the earth resound.
chunk_3.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 3

chunk_4.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 20: 1.20. Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra’s party standing
arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of
Pandu, whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following
to Krishna, O Lord of the earth. Chapter 1, Verse 21: 1.21 Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence. Chapter 1, Verse 22: 1.22. Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence. Chapter 1, Verse 23: 1.23. For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight,
wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana (the son of Dhritarashtra).
chunk_4.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 4

chunk_5.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 24: 1.24. Sanjaya said  Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna, having stationed that
best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies. Chapter 1, Verse 25: 1.25. In front of Bhishma and Drona, and all the rulers of the
earth, said: "O Arjuna (son of Pritha), behold these Kurus gathered together." Chapter 1, Verse 26: 1.26. Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed,
fathers and grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons
and friends too. Chapter 1, Verse 27: 1.27. (He saw) fathers-in-law and friends also in both the armies.
The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed,
spoke this, sorrowfully filled with deep pity. Chapter 1, Verse 28: 1.28. Arjuna said  Seeing these, my kinsmen, O krishna, arrayed, eager to fight.
chunk_5.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 5

chunk_6.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 29: 1.29. My limbs fail and my mouth is parched, my body ivers and
my hair stands on end. Chapter 1, Verse 30: 1.30. The (bow) Gandiva slips from my hand, and also my skins burns
all over; I am unable even to stand and my mind is reeling, as it were. Chapter 1, Verse 31: 1.31. And I see adverse omens, O Kesava. I do not see any good
in killing my kinsmen in battle. Chapter 1, Verse 32: 1.32. I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
Of what avail is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life? Chapter 1, Verse 33: 1.33. Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments and pleasures,
stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.
chunk_6.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 6

chunk_7.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 34: 1.34. Teachers, fathers, sons and also grandfathers, maternal uncles,
fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives,- Chapter 1, Verse 35: 1.35. These I do not wish to kill, though they kill me, O Krishna,
even for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing
them for the sake of the earth. Chapter 1, Verse 36: 1.36. By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure can
be ours, O Janardana? Only sin will accrue to us from killing these felons. Chapter 1, Verse 37: 1.37. Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra,
our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own people, O Madhava
(Krishna)? Chapter 1, Verse 38: 1.38. Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see
no evil in the destruction of families, and no sin in hostility to friends,
chunk_7.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 7

chunk_8.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 39: 1.39. Why should not we who clearly see evil in the destruction
of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)? Chapter 1, Verse 40: 1.40. In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious
rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety,
indeed, overcomes the whole family. Chapter 1, Verse 41: 1.41. By the prevalence of impiety, O Krishna, the women of
the family become corrupt; and , women being corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant
of Vrishni), there arises intermingling of castes. Chapter 1, Verse 42: 1.42. Confusion of castes leads to hell the slayers of the family,
for their forefathers fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-ball and
water (libations). Chapter 1, Verse 43: 1.43. By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which
cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and
the family are destroyed.
chunk_8.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 8

chunk_9.content:
Chapter 1, Verse 44: 1.44. We have heard, O Janardana, that inevitable is the dwelling
for an unknown period in hell for those men in whose families the religious
practices have been destroyed. Chapter 1, Verse 45: 1.45. Alas! We are involved in a great sin, in that we are
prepared to kill our kinsmen, through greed for the pleasures of a kingdom. Chapter 1, Verse 46: 1.46. If the sons of Dhritarashtra with weapons in hand should
slay me in battle, unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me. Chapter 1, Verse 47: 1.47. Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna,
casting away his bow and arrow, sat down on the seat of the chariot with
his mind overwhelmed with sorrow. Chapter 2, Verse 1: 2.1 Sanjaya said  To him who was thus overcome with pity and who was despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.
chunk_9.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 9

chunk_10.content: Chapter 2, Verse 2: 2.2 The Blessed Lord said  Whence is this perilous strait come upon thee, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna? Chapter 2, Verse 3: 2.3 Yield not to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit thee. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O scorcher of the foes! Chapter 2, Verse 4: 2.4 Arjuna said  How, O Madhusudana, shall I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are fit to be worshipped, O destroyer of enemies? Chapter 2, Verse 5: 2.5 Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I kill them, even in this world all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires will be stained with (their) blood.
chunk_10.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 10

chunk_11.content: Chapter 2, Verse 6: 2.6 I can hardly tell which will be better, that we should  coner them or that they should coner us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, after slaying whom we do not wish to live, stand facing us. Chapter 2, Verse 7: 2.7 My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple. Instruct me who has taken refuge in Thee. Chapter 2, Verse 8: 2.8 I do not see that it would remove this sorrow that burns up my senses, even if I should attain prosperous and unrivalled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods. Chapter 2, Verse 9: 2.9 Sanjaya said  Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha (the Lord of the senses), Arjuna (the coneror of sleep), the destroyer of foes, said to Krishna, "I will not fight" and became silent. Chapter 2, Verse 10: 2.10 To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, as if smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.
chunk_11.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 11

chunk_12.content: Chapter 2, Verse 11: 2.11 The Blessed Lord said  Thou hast grieved for those that should not be grieved for, yet thou speakest words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead. Chapter 2, Verse 12: 2.12 Nor at any time indeed was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men, nor verily shall we ever cease to be hereafter. Chapter 2, Verse 13: 2.13 Just as in this body the embodied (soul) passes into childhood, youth and old age, so also does it pass into another body; the firm man does not grieve thereat. Chapter 2, Verse 14: 2.14 The contacts of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which cause heat and cold, pleasure and pain, have a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna. Chapter 2, Verse 15: 2.15 That firm man whom, surely, these afflict not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
chunk_12.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 12

chunk_13.content: Chapter 2, Verse 16: 2.16 The unreal hath no being; there is non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the Truth (or the seers of the Essence). Chapter 2, Verse 17: 2.17 Know that to be indestructible, by Which all this is pervaded. None can cause the destruction of That, the Imperishable. Chapter 2, Verse 18: 2.18 These bodies of the embodied Self, Which is eternal, indestructible and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore fight, O Arjuna. Chapter 2, Verse 19: 2.19 He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks It is slain, neither of them ï1knowsï1. It slays not, nor is It slain. Chapter 2, Verse 20: 2.20 It is not born, nor does It ever die; after having been, It again ceases not to be; unborn, eternal, changeless and ancient, It is not killed when the body is killed.
chunk_13.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 13

chunk_14.content: Chapter 2, Verse 21: 2.21 Whosoever knows It to be indestructible, eternal, unborn and inexhaustible, how can that man slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain? Chapter 2, Verse 22: 2.22 Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so also the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others which are new. Chapter 2, Verse 23: 2.23 Weapons cut It not, fire burns It not, water wets It not, wind dries It not. Chapter 2, Verse 24: 2.24 This Self cannot be cut, burnt, wetted, nor dried up. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, immovable and ancient. Chapter 2, Verse 25: 2.25 This (Self) is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing This to be such, thou shouldst not grieve.
chunk_14.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 14

chunk_15.content: Chapter 2, Verse 26: 2.26 But even if thou thinkest of It as being constantly born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed, thou shouldst not grieve. Chapter 2, Verse 27: 2.27 For certain is death for the born, and certain is birth for the dead; therefore, over the inevitable thou shouldst not grieve. Chapter 2, Verse 28: 2.28 Beings are unmanifested in their beginning, manifested in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifested again in their end. What is there to grieve about? Chapter 2, Verse 29: 2.29 One sees This (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of It as a wonder; another hears of It as a wonder; yet having heard, none understands It at all. Chapter 2, Verse 30: 2.30 This, the Indweller in the body of everyone, is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, thou shouldst not grieve for any creature.
chunk_15.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 15

chunk_16.content: Chapter 2, Verse 31: 2.31 Further, having regard to thy duty, shouldst not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war. Chapter 2, Verse 32: 2.32 Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called upon to fight in such a battle that comes of itself as an open door to heaven. Chapter 2, Verse 33: 2.33 But if thou wilt not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned thine own duty and fame, thou shalt incur sin. Chapter 2, Verse 34: 2.34 People, too, will recount thy everlasting dishonour; and to one who has been honoured, dishonour is worse than death. Chapter 2, Verse 35: 2.35 The great car-warriors will think that thou hast withdrawn from the battle through fear; and thou wilt be lightly held by them who have thought much of thee.
chunk_16.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 16

chunk_17.content: Chapter 2, Verse 36: 2.36 Thy enemies also, cavilling at thy power, will speak many abusive words. What is more painful than this? Chapter 2, Verse 37: 2.37 Slain, thou wilt obtain heaven; victorious, thou wilt enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight. Chapter 2, Verse 38: 2.38 Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat the same, engage thou in battle for the sake of battle; thus thou shalt not incur sin. Chapter 2, Verse 39: 2.39 This, which has been taught to thee, is wisdon concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, thou shalt cast off the bonds of action. Chapter 2, Verse 40: 2.40 In this there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm (production of contrary results or transgression). Even a little of this knowledge (even a little practice of this Yoga) protects one from great fear.
chunk_17.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 17

chunk_18.content: Chapter 2, Verse 41: 2.41 Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is but a single one-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the irresolute. Chapter 2, Verse 42: 2.42 Flowery speech is uttered by the unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogising words of the Vedas, O Arjuna, saying, "There is nothing else." Chapter 2, Verse 43: 2.43 Full of desires, having heaven as their goal, (they utter speech which is directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power. Chapter 2, Verse 44: 2.44 For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teaching, ï1thatï1 determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).
chunk_18.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 18

chunk_19.content: Chapter 2, Verse 45: 2.45 The Vedas deal with the three attributes (of Nature); be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites, and ever remain in the ality of Sattva (goodness), freed from (the thought of) acisition and preservation, and be established in the Self. Chapter 2, Verse 46: 2.46 To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as is a reservoir of water in a place where there is a flood. Chapter 2, Verse 47: 2.47 Thy right is to work only, but never with its fruits; let not the fruits of action be thy motive, nor let thy attachment be to inaction. Chapter 2, Verse 48: 2.48 Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure. Evenness of mind is called Yoga. Chapter 2, Verse 49: 2.49 Far lower than the Yoga of wisdon is action, O Arjuna. Seek thou refuge in wisdom; wretched are they whose motive is the fruit.
chunk_19.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 19

chunk_20.content: Chapter 2, Verse 50: 2.50 Endowed with wisdom (evenness of mind), one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote thyself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action. Chapter 2, Verse 51: 2.51 The wise, possessed of knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the fetters of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil. Chapter 2, Verse 52: 2.52 When thy intellect crosses beyond the mire of delusion, then thou shalt attain to indifference as to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard. Chapter 2, Verse 53: 2.53 When thy intellect, which is perplexed by the Veda text, which thou hast read, shall stand immovable and steady in the Self, then thou shalt attain Self-realisation. Chapter 2, Verse 54: 2.54 Arjuna said  What, O Krishna, is the description of him who has steady wisdom, and is merged in the superconscious state? How does one of steady wisdom speak, how does he sit, how does he walk?
chunk_20.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 20

chunk_21.content: Chapter 2, Verse 55: 2.55 The Blessed Lord said  When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then is he said to be one of steady wisdom. Chapter 2, Verse 56: 2.56 He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not hanker after pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom. Chapter 2, Verse 57: 2.57 He who is everywhere without attachment, on meeting with anything good or bad, who neither rejoices not hastes, his wisdom is fixed. Chapter 2, Verse 58: 2.58 When, like the tortoise which withdraws on all sides its limbs, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady. Chapter 2, Verse 59: 2.59 The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man leaving the longing (behind); but his longing also turns away on seeing the Supreme.
chunk_21.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 21

chunk_22.content: Chapter 2, Verse 60: 2.60 The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, do violently carry away the mind of a wise man though he be striving (to control them). Chapter 2, Verse 61: 2.61 Having restrained them all he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control. Chapter 2, Verse 62: 2.62 When a man thinks of the objects, attachment for them arises; from attachment desire is born; from desire anger arises. Chapter 2, Verse 63: 2.63 From anger comes delusion; from delusion loss of memory; from loss of memory the destruction of discrimination; from the destruction of discrimination he perishes. Chapter 2, Verse 64: 2.64 But the self-controlled man, moving among the objects with the senses under restraint and free from attraction and repulsion, attains to peace. Chapter 2, Verse 65: 2.65 In that peace all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranil-minded soon becomes steady.
chunk_22.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 22

chunk_23.content: Chapter 2, Verse 66: 2.66 There is no knowledge of the Self to the unsteady and to the unsteady no meditation is possible, and to the unmeditative there can be no peace, and to the man who has no peace, how can there be happiness? Chapter 2, Verse 67: 2.67 For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind (carries away) a boat on the waters. Chapter 2, Verse 68: 2.68 Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense-objects. Chapter 2, Verse 69: 2.69 That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the Muni (sage) who sees. Chapter 2, Verse 70: 2.70 He attains peace into whom all desires enter as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.
chunk_23.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 23

chunk_24.content: Chapter 2, Verse 71: 2.71 That man attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of mine and without egoism. Chapter 2, Verse 72: 2.72 This is the Brahmic seat (eternal state), O son of Pritha. Attaining to this, none is deluded. Being established therein, even at the end of life, one attains to oneness with Brahman. Chapter 3, Verse 1: 3.1 Arjuna said  If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, dost Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action? Chapter 3, Verse 2: 3.2 With this apparently perplexing speech, Thou confusest, as it were, my understanding; therefore tell me that one way for certain by which I may attain bliss. Chapter 3, Verse 3: 3.3 The Blessed Lord said  In this world there is a twofold path, as I said before, O sinless one; the path of knowledge of the Sankhyas and the path of action of the Yogins.
chunk_24.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 24

chunk_25.content: Chapter 3, Verse 4: 3.4 Not by non-performance of actions does man reach actionlessness; nor by mere renunciation does he attain to perfection. Chapter 3, Verse 5: 3.5 Verily none can ever remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly indeed by the alities born of Nature. Chapter 3, Verse 6: 3.6 He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of the sense-objects in mind, he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite. Chapter 3, Verse 7: 3.7 But whosoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels. Chapter 3, Verse 8: 3.8 Do thou perform (thy) bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for thee by inaction.
chunk_25.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 25

chunk_26.content: Chapter 3, Verse 9: 3.9 The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform action for that sake (for sacrifice alone), free from attachment. Chapter 3, Verse 10: 3.10 The Creator, having in the beginning (of creation) created mankind together with sacrifice, said, "By this shall ye propagate; let this be the milch cow of your desires (the cow which yields all the desired objects)." Chapter 3, Verse 11: 3.11 With this do ye nourish the gods and may those gods nourish you; thus nourishing one another, ye shall attain to the highest good. Chapter 3, Verse 12: 3.12 The gods, nourished by the sacrifice, will give you the desired objects. So, he who enjoys the objects given by the gods without offering (in return) to them, is verily a thief. Chapter 3, Verse 13: 3.13 The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food (only) for their own sake verily eat sin.
chunk_26.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 26

chunk_27.content: Chapter 3, Verse 14: 3.14 From food come forth beings; from rain food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain and sacrifice is born of action. Chapter 3, Verse 15: 3.15 Know thou that action comes from Brahma and Brahma comes from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervading (Brahma) ever rests in sacrifice. Chapter 3, Verse 16: 3.16 He who does not follow here the wheel thus set revolving, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, he lives in vain, O Arjuna. Chapter 3, Verse 17: 3.17 But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and who is content in the Self alone, verily there is nothing to do. Chapter 3, Verse 18: 3.18 For him there is no interest whatever in what is done or what is not done; nor does he depend on any being for any object.
chunk_27.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 27

chunk_28.content: Chapter 3, Verse 19: 3.19 Therefore without attachment, do thou always perform action which should be done; for by performing action without attachment man reaches the Supreme. Chapter 3, Verse 20: 3.20 Janaka and others attained perfection verily by action only; even with a view to the protection of the masses thou shouldst perform action. Chapter 3, Verse 21: 3.21 Whatsoever a great man does, that the other men also do; whatever he sets up as the standard, that the world (mankind) follows. Chapter 3, Verse 22: 3.22 There is nothing in the three worlds, O Arjuna, that should be done by Me, nor is there anything unattained that should be attained; yet I engage Myself in action. Chapter 3, Verse 23: 3.23 For, should I not ever engage Myself in action, unwearied, men would in every way follow My path, O Arjuna.
chunk_28.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 28

chunk_29.content: Chapter 3, Verse 24: 3.24 These worlds would perish if I did not perform action; I should be the author of confusion of castes and destruction of these beings. Chapter 3, Verse 25: 3.25 As the ignorant men act from attachment to action, O Bharata (Arjuna), so should the wise act without attachment, wishing the welfare of the world. Chapter 3, Verse 26: 3.26 Let no wise man unsettle the mind of ignorant people who are attached to action; he should engage them in all actions, himself fulfilling them with devotion. Chapter 3, Verse 27: 3.27 All actions are wrought in all cases by the alities of Nature only. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, "I am the doer." Chapter 3, Verse 28: 3.28 But he who knows the Truth, O mighty-armed (Arjuna), about the divisions of the alities and (their) functions, knowing that the Gunas as senses move amidst the Gunas as the sense-objects, is not attached.
chunk_29.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 29

chunk_30.content:
Chapter 3, Verse 29: 3.29 Those deluded by the alities of Nature are attached to the functions of the alities. The man of perfect knowledge should not unsettle the foolish one who is of imperfect knowledge. Chapter 3, Verse 30: 3.30 Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centred in the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from (mental) fever, do thou fight. Chapter 3, Verse 31: 3.31 Those men who constantly practise this teaching of Mine with faith and without cavilling, they too are freed from actions. Chapter 3, Verse 32: 3.32 But those who carp at My teaching and do not practise it, deluded of all knowledge, and devoid of discrimination, know them to be doomed to destruction. Chapter 3, Verse 33: 3.33 Even a wise man acts in accordance with his own nature; beings will follow Nature; what can 
restraint do?
chunk_30.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 30

chunk_31.content: Chapter 3, Verse 34: 3.34 Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let none come under their sway; for, they are his foes. Chapter 3, Verse 35: 3.35 Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear (is productive of danger). Chapter 3, Verse 36: 3.36 Arjuna said  But impelled by what does man commit sin, though against his wishes, O Varshneya (Krishna), constrained as it were, by force? Chapter 3, Verse 37: 3.37 The Blessed Lord said  It is desire, it is anger both of the ality of Rajas, all-devouring, all-sinful; know this as the foe here (in this world). Chapter 3, Verse 38: 3.38 As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror by dust, and as an embryo by the amnion, so is this enveloped by that.
chunk_31.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 31

chunk_32.content: Chapter 3, Verse 39: 3.39 O Arjuna, wisdom is enveloped by this constant enemy of the wise in the form of desire, which is unappeasable as fire. Chapter 3, Verse 40: 3.40 The senses, the mind and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these it deludes the embodied by veiling his wisdom. Chapter 3, Verse 41: 3.41 Therefore, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), controlling the senses first, do thou kill this sinful thing, the destroyer of knowledge and realisation. Chapter 3, Verse 42: 3.42 They say that the senses are superior (to the body); superior to the senses is the mind; superior to the mind is the intellect; one who is superior even to the intellect is He (the Self). Chapter 3, Verse 43: 3.43 Thus knowing Him Who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to coner.
chunk_32.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 32

chunk_33.content: Chapter 4, Verse 1: 4.1 The Blessed Lord said  I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan; he told it to Manu; Manu proclaimed it to Ikshvaku. Chapter 4, Verse 2: 4.2 This, handed down thus in regular succession, the royal sages knew. This Yoga, by long lapse of time, has been lost here, O Parantapa (burner of the foes). Chapter 4, Verse 3: 4.3 That same ancient Yoga has been today taught to thee by Me, for thou art My devotee and My friend; it is the supreme secret. Chapter 4, Verse 4: 4.4 Arjuna said  Later on was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou taughtest this Yoga in the beginning? Chapter 4, Verse 5: 4.5 The Blessed Lord said  Many births of Mine have passed as well as of thine, O Arjuna; I know them all but thou knowest not, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes).
chunk_33.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 33

chunk_34.content: Chapter 4, Verse 6: 4.6 Though I am unborn, of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing My own Nature, I am born by My own Maya. Chapter 4, Verse 7: 4.7 Whenever there is decline of righteousness, O Arjuna, and rise of unrighteousness, then I manifest Myself. Chapter 4, Verse 8: 4.8 For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age. Chapter 4, Verse 9: 4.9 He who thus know, in their true light, My divine birth and action, having abandoned the body, is not born again, he comes to Me, O Arjuna. Chapter 4, Verse 10: 4.10 Freed from attachment, fear and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained to My Being.
chunk_34.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 34

chunk_35.content: Chapter 4, Verse 11: 4.11 In whatever way men approach Me even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna. Chapter 4, Verse 12: 4.12 Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; because success is ickly attained by men through action. Chapter 4, Verse 13: 4.13 The fourfold caste has been created by Me according to the differentiation of Guna and Karma; though I am the author thereof know Me as non-doer and immutable. Chapter 4, Verse 14: 4.14 Actions do not taint Me, nor have I a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions. Chapter 4, Verse 15: 4.15 Having known this, the ancient seekers after freedom also performed action; therefore do thou also perform action, as did the ancients in days of yore.
chunk_35.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 35

chunk_36.content:
Chapter 4, Verse 16: 4.16 What is action? What is inaction? As to this even the wise are confused. Therefore I shall teach thee such action (the nature of action and inaction) by knowing which thou shalt be liberated from the evil (of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death). Chapter 4, Verse 17: 4.17 For verily (the true nature) of action (enjoined by the scriptures) should be known, also (that) 
of forbidden (or unlawful) action, and of inaction; hard to understand is the nature (path) of action. Chapter 4, Verse 18: 4.18 He who seeth inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men; he is a Yogi and performer of all actions. Chapter 4, Verse 19: 4.19 He whose undertakings are all devoid of desires and (selfish) purposes and whose actions have been burnt by the fire of knowledge,  him the wise call a sage. Chapter 4, Verse 20: 4.20 Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything though engaged in activity.
chunk_36.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 36

chunk_37.content: Chapter 4, Verse 21: 4.21 Without hope and with the mind and the self controlled, having abandoned all covetousness, doing mere bodily action, he incurs no sin. Chapter 4, Verse 22: 4.22 Content with what comes to him without effort, free from the pairs of opposites and envy, even-minded in success and failure, though acting, he is not bound. Chapter 4, Verse 23: 4.23 To one who is devoid of attchment, who is liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, who works for the sake of sacrifice (for the sake of God), the whole action is dissolved. Chapter 4, Verse 24: 4.24 Brahman is the oblation; Brahman is the melted butter (ghee); by Brahman is the oblation poured into the fire of Brahman; Brahman verily shall be reached by him who always sees Brahman in action. Chapter 4, Verse 25: 4.25 Some Yogies perform sacrifice to the gods alone; while others (who have realised the Self) offer the self as sacrifice by the Self in the fire of Brahman alone.
chunk_37.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 37

chunk_38.content: Chapter 4, Verse 26: 4.26 Some again offer the organ of hearing and other senses as sacrifice in the fire of restraint; others offer sound and other objects of the senses as sacrifice in the fire of the senses. Chapter 4, Verse 27: 4.27 Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint kindled by knowledge. Chapter 4, Verse 28: 4.28 Others again offer wealth, austerity and Yoga as sacrifice, while the ascetics of self-restraint and rigid vows offer study of scriptures and knowledge as sacrifice. Chapter 4, Verse 29: 4.29 Others offer as sacrifice the outgoing breath in the incoming, and the incoming in the outgoing, restraining the course of the outgoing and the incoming breaths, solely absorbed in the restraint of the breath. Chapter 4, Verse 30: 4.30 Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in life-breaths. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed by sacrifice.
chunk_38.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 38

chunk_39.content: Chapter 4, Verse 31: 4.31 Those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, which are like nectar, go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the man who does not perform sacrifice; how then can he have the other, O Arjuna? Chapter 4, Verse 32: 4.32 Thus, manifold sacrifices are spread out before Brahman (literally) at the mouth or face of Brahman). Know them all as born of action and thus knowing, thou shalt be liberated. Chapter 4, Verse 33: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka Chapter 4, Verse 34: 4.34 Know That by long prostration, by estion and by service; the wise who have realised the Truth will instruct thee in (that) knowledge. Chapter 4, Verse 35: 4.35 Knowing ï1thatï1 thou shalt not, O Arjuna, again get deluded like this; and by that thou shalt see all beings in thy Self and also in Me.
chunk_39.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 39

chunk_40.content: Chapter 4, Verse 36: 4.36 Even if thou art the most sinful of all sinners, yet thou shalt verily cross all sins by the raft of knowledge. Chapter 4, Verse 37: 4.37 As the blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes. Chapter 4, Verse 38: 4.38 Verily, there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it in the Self in time. Chapter 4, Verse 39: 4.39 The man who is full of faith, who is devoted to it, and who has subdued the senses obtains (this) knowledge; and having obtained the knowledge he attains at once to the supreme peace. Chapter 4, Verse 40: 4.40 The ignorant the faithless, the doubting self goes to destruction; there is neither this world nor the other, nor happiness for the doubting.
chunk_40.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 40

chunk_41.content: Chapter 4, Verse 41: 4.41 He who has renounced actions by Yoga, whose doubts are rent asunder by knowledge, and who is self-possessed  actions do not bind him, O Arjuna. Chapter 4, Verse 42: 4.42 Therefore with the sword of the knowledge (of the Self) cut asunder the doubt of the self born of ignorance, residing in thy heart, and take refuge in Yoga. Arise, O Arjuna. Chapter 5, Verse 1: 5.1 Arjuna said  Renunciation of actions, O Krishna, Thou praisest, and again Yoga. Tell me conclusively that which is the better of the two. Chapter 5, Verse 2: 5.2 The Blessed Lord said  Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action. Chapter 5, Verse 3: 5.3 He should be known as a perpertual Sannyasi who neither hates nor desires; for, free from the pairs of opposites, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he is easily set free from bondage.
chunk_41.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 41

chunk_42.content: Chapter 5, Verse 4: 5.4 Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action or the performance of action as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one obtains the fruits of both. Chapter 5, Verse 5: 5.5 That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He sees, who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one. Chapter 5, Verse 6: 5.6 But renunciation, O mighty-armed Arjuna, is hard to attain without Yoga; the Yoga-harmonised sage ickly goes to Brahman. Chapter 5, Verse 7: 5.7 He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is ite pure, who has conered the self, who has subdued his senses and who realises his Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted. Chapter 5, Verse 8: 5.8 "I do nothing at all," thus would the harmonised knower of Truth think  seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, breathing.
chunk_42.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 42

chunk_43.content: Chapter 5, Verse 9: 5.9 Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening and closing the eyes  convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects. Chapter 5, Verse 10: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water. Chapter 5, Verse 11: 5.11 Yogis, having abandoned attachment, perform actions only by the body, mind, intellect, and even by the senses, for the purification of the self. Chapter 5, Verse 12: 5.12 The united one (the well poised or the harmonised) having abandoned the fruit of action attains to the eternal peace: the non-united only (the unsteady or the unbalanced) impelled by desire, attached to the fruit, is bound. Chapter 5, Verse 13: 5.13 Mentally renouncing all actions and self-controlled, the embodied one rests happily in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.
chunk_43.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 43

chunk_44.content: Chapter 5, Verse 14: 5.14 Neither agency nor actions does the Lord create for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions. But it is Nature that acts. Chapter 5, Verse 15: 5.15 The Lord takes neither the demerit nor even the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, thery beings are deluded. Chapter 5, Verse 16: 5.16 But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by the knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme (Brahman). Chapter 5, Verse 17: 5.17 Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That for their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge. Chapter 5, Verse 18: 5.18 Sages look with an eal eye on a Brahmana endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, on an elephant, and even on a dog and an outcaste.
chunk_44.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 44

chunk_45.content: Chapter 5, Verse 19: 5.19 Even here (in this world) birth (everything) is overcome by those whose minds rest in eality; Brahman is spotless indeed and eal; therefore they are established in Brahman. Chapter 5, Verse 20: 5.20 Resting in Brahman, with steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoiceth on obtaining what is pleasant nor grieveth on obtaining what is unpleasant. Chapter 5, Verse 21: 5.21 With the self unattached to external contacts he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in    the meditation of Brahman he attains to the endless happiness. Chapter 5, Verse 22: 5.22 The enjoyments that are born of contacts are only generators of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise man does not rejoice in them. Chapter 5, Verse 23: 5.23 He who is able, while still here (in this world) to withstand, before the liberation from the body, the impulse born out of desire and anger  he is a Yogi, he is a happy man.
chunk_45.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 45

chunk_46.content: Chapter 5, Verse 24: 5.24 He who is happy within, who rejoices within, and who is illuminated within, that Yogi attains absolute freedom or Moksha, himself becoming Brahman. Chapter 5, Verse 25: 5.25 The sages (Rishis) obtain absolute freedom or Moksha  they whose sins have been destroyed, whose dualities (perception of dualities or experience of the pairs of opposites) are torn asunder, who are self-controlled, and intent on the welfare of all beings. Chapter 5, Verse 26: 5.26 Absolute freedom (or Brahmic bliss) exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts and who have realised the Self. Chapter 5, Verse 27: 5.27 Shutting out (all) external contacts and fixing the gaze between the eyrow, ealising the outgoing and incoming breaths moving within the nostrils. Chapter 5, Verse 28: 5.28 With the senses, the mind and the intellect (ever) controlled, having liberation as his supreme goal, free from desire, fear and anger  the sage is verily liberated for ever.
chunk_46.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 46

chunk_47.content: Chapter 5, Verse 29: 5.29 He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds and the friend of all beings, attains to peace. Chapter 6, Verse 1: 6.1 The Blessed Lord said  He who performs his bounden duty without depending on the fruits of his actions  he is a Sannyasi and a Yogi; not he who is without fire and without action. Chapter 6, Verse 2: 6.2 Do thou, O Arjuna, know Yoga to be that which they call renunciation; no one verily becomes a Yogi who has not renounced thoughts. Chapter 6, Verse 3: 6.3 For a sage who wishes to attain to Yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained to Yoga, inaction (iescence) is said to be the means. Chapter 6, Verse 4: 6.4 When a man is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then he is said to have attained to Yoga.
chunk_47.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 47

chunk_48.content: Chapter 6, Verse 5: 6.5 One should raise oneself by one's Self alone; let not one lower oneself; for the Self alone is the friend of oneself, and the Self alone is the enemy of oneself. Chapter 6, Verse 6: 6.6 The Self is the friend of the self of him by whom the self has been conered by the Self, but to the unconered self, this Self stands in the position of an enemy, like an (external) foe. Chapter 6, Verse 7: 6.7 The Supreme Self of him who is self-controlled and peaceful is balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as also in honour and dishonour. Chapter 6, Verse 8: 6.8 The Yogi who is satisfied with the knowledge and the wisdom (of the Self), who has conered the senses, and to whom a clod of earth, a piece of stone and gold are the same, is said to be harmonied (i.e., is said to have attained Nirvikalpa Samadhi). Chapter 6, Verse 9: 6.9 He who is of the same mind to the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous and the unrighteous, excels.
chunk_48.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 48

chunk_49.content: Chapter 6, Verse 10: 6.10 Let the Yogi try constantly to keep the mind steady, remaining in solitude, alone, with the mind and the body controlled, and free from hope and covetousness. Chapter 6, Verse 11: 6.11 In a clean spot, having established a firm seat of his own, neither too high nor too low, made of a cloth, a skin and Kusa-grass, one over the other. Chapter 6, Verse 12: 6.12 There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and the senses controlled, let him, seated on the seat, practise Yoga for the purification of the self. Chapter 6, Verse 13: 6.13 Let him firmly hold his body, head and neck erect and still, gazing at the tip of his nose, without looking around. Chapter 6, Verse 14: 6.14 Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled the mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let him sit, having Me as his supreme goal.
chunk_49.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 49

chunk_50.content:
Chapter 6, Verse 15: 6.15 Thus always keeping the mind balanced, the Yogi, with the mind controlled, attains to the peace abiding in Me, which culminates in liberation. Chapter 6, Verse 16: 6.16 Verily Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is (always) awake, O Arjuna. Chapter 6, Verse 17: 6.17 Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation (such 
as walking, etc.), who is moderate in exertion in actions, who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness. Chapter 6, Verse 18: 6.18 When the perfectly controlled mind rests in the Self only, free from longing for all the objects of desires, then it is said, 'He is united'. Chapter 6, Verse 19: 6.19 As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker  to such is compared the Yogi of controlled mind, practising Yoga in the Self (or absorbed in the Yoga of the Self).
chunk_50.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 50

chunk_51.content: Chapter 6, Verse 20: 6.20 When the mind, restrained by the practice of Yoga attains to quietude and when seeing the Self by the self, he is satisfied in his own Self. Chapter 6, Verse 21: 6.21 When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite Bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses, and established wherein he never moves from the Reality. Chapter 6, Verse 22: 6.22 Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein estabished, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow. Chapter 6, Verse 23: 6.23 Let that be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with an undesponding mind. Chapter 6, Verse 24: 6.24 Abandoning without reserve all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of the senses by the mind from all sides.
chunk_51.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 51

chunk_52.content: Chapter 6, Verse 25: 6.25 Little by little let him attain to ietude by the intellect held firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything. Chapter 6, Verse 26: 6.26 From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, from that let him restrain it and bring it under the control of the Self alone. Chapter 6, Verse 27: 6.27 Supreme Bliss verily comes to this Yogi whose mind is ite peaceful, whose passion is ieted, who has become Brahman and who is free from sin. Chapter 6, Verse 28: 6.28 The Yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of Yoga), freed from sins, easily enjoys the Infinite Bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal). Chapter 6, Verse 29: 6.29 With the mind harmonised by Yoga he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
chunk_52.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 52

chunk_53.content: Chapter 6, Verse 30: 6.30 He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, he never becomes separated from Me, nor do I become separated from him. Chapter 6, Verse 31: 6.31 He who, being established in unity, worships Me Who dwells in all beings, that Yogi abides in Me, whatever may be his mode of living. Chapter 6, Verse 32: 6.32 He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees eality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, he is regarded as the highest Yogi. Chapter 6, Verse 33: 6.33 Arjuna said  This Yoga of eanimity taught by Thee, O Krishna, I do not see its steady continuance, because of the restlessness (of the mind). Chapter 6, Verse 34: 6.34 The mind verily is restless, turbulent, strong and unyielding, O Krishna: I deem it as difficult to control it as to control the wind.
chunk_53.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 53

chunk_54.content: Chapter 6, Verse 35: 6.35 The Blessed Lord said  Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but by practice and by dispassion it may be restrained. Chapter 6, Verse 36: 6.36 I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one of uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain to it by the (proper) means. Chapter 6, Verse 37: 6.37 Arjuna said  He who is unable to control himself though he has the faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, mee,t O Krishna? Chapter 6, Verse 38: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka Chapter 6, Verse 39: 6.39 This doubt of mine, O Krishna, do Thou dispel completely; because it is not possible for any but Thee to dispel this doubt.
chunk_54.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 54

chunk_55.content: Chapter 6, Verse 40: 6.40 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, neither in this world, nor in the next world is there destruction for him; none, verily, who does good, O My son, ever comes to grief. Chapter 6, Verse 41: 6.41 Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is rorn in a house of the pure and wealthy. Chapter 6, Verse 42: 6.42 Or he is born in a family of even the wise Yogis; verily a birth like this is very difficult to obtain in this world. Chapter 6, Verse 43: 6.43 Thee he comes in touch with the knowledge acired in his former body and strives more than before for perfection, O Arjuna. Chapter 6, Verse 44: 6.44 By that very former practice he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmic word.
chunk_55.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 55

chunk_56.content: Chapter 6, Verse 45: 6.45 But the Yogi who strives with assiduity, purified of sins and perfected gradually through many births, reaches the highest goal. Chapter 6, Verse 46: 6.46 The Yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics and even superior to men of knowledge (obtained through the study of scriptures); he is also superior to men of action; therefore be thou a Yogi, O Arjuna. Chapter 6, Verse 47: 6.47 And among all the Yogis he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devout. Chapter 7, Verse 1: 7.1 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, hear how you shall without doubt know Me fully, with the mind intent on Me, practising Yoga and taking refuge in Me. Chapter 7, Verse 2: 7.2 I shall declare to thee in full this knowledge combined with realisation, after knowing which nothing more here remains to be known.
chunk_56.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 56

chunk_57.content: Chapter 7, Verse 3: 7.3 Among thousands of men, one perchance strives for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one perchance knows Me in essence. Chapter 7, Verse 4: 7.4 Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and egoism  thus is My Nature divided eightfold. Chapter 7, Verse 5: 7.5 This is the inferior Prakriti, O mighty-armed (Arjuna); know thou as different from it My higher Prakriti (Nature), the very life-element, by which this world is upheld. Chapter 7, Verse 6: 7.6 Know that these two (Natures) are the womb of all beings. So I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe. Chapter 7, Verse 7: 7.7 There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, as clusters of gems on a string.
chunk_57.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 57

chunk_58.content: Chapter 7, Verse 8: 7.8 I am the sapidity in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in ether and virility in men. Chapter 7, Verse 9: 7.9 I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity in ascetics. Chapter 7, Verse 10: 7.10 Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent; the splendour of the splendid objects am I. Chapter 7, Verse 11: 7.11 Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in (all) beings, I am the desire unopposed to Dharma, O Arjuna. Chapter 7, Verse 12: 7.12 Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.
chunk_58.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 58

chunk_59.content: Chapter 7, Verse 13: 7.13 Deluded by these Natures (states or things) composed of the three alities of Nature all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable. Chapter 7, Verse 14: 7.14 Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, made up of the (three) alities (of Nature) is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, cross over this illusion. Chapter 7, Verse 15: 7.15 The evil-doers and the deluded who are the lowest of men do not seek Me; they whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons. Chapter 7, Verse 16: 7.16 Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekr of knowledge, the seekr of wealth and the wise, O lord of the Bharatas. Chapter 7, Verse 17: 7.17 Of them the wise, ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excels (is the best); for I am exceedingly dear to the wise and he is dear to Me.
chunk_59.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 59

chunk_60.content: Chapter 7, Verse 18: 7.18 Noble indeed are all these; but I deem the wise man as My very Self; for, steadfast in mind he is established in Me alone as the supreme goal. Chapter 7, Verse 19: 7.19 At the end of many births the wise man comes to Me, realising that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find. Chapter 7, Verse 20: 7.20 Those whose wisdom has been rent away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature. Chapter 7, Verse 21: 7.21 Whatsoever form any devotee desires to worship with faith  that (same) faith of his I make firm and unflinching. Chapter 7, Verse 22: 7.22 Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that (form) and from it he obtains his desire, these being verily ordained by Me (alone).
chunk_60.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 60

chunk_61.content: Chapter 7, Verse 23: 7.23 Verily the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, but My devotees come to Me. Chapter 7, Verse 24: 7.24 The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, knowing not My higher, immutable and most excellent nature. Chapter 7, Verse 25: 7.25 I am not manifest to all (as I am) veiled by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, the unborn and imperishable. Chapter 7, Verse 26: 7.26 I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present and the future, but no one knows Me. Chapter 7, Verse 27: 7.27 By the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth, O Parantapa.
chunk_61.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 61

chunk_62.content: Chapter 7, Verse 28: 7.28 But those men of virtuous deeds whose sins have come to an end, and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me, steadfast in their vows. Chapter 7, Verse 29: 7.29 Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realise in full ï1thatï1 Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self and all action. Chapter 7, Verse 30: 7.30 Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods) and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, steadfast in mind. Chapter 8, Verse 1: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka Chapter 8, Verse 2: 8.2 Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu (Krishna)? And how at the time of death, art Thou to be known by the self-controlled?
chunk_62.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 62

chunk_63.content: Chapter 8, Verse 3: 8.3 The Blessed Lord said  Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; Its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) which causes existence and manifestation of beings and which also sustains them is called action. Chapter 8, Verse 4: 8.4 Adhibhuta (knowledge of the elements) pertains to My perishable Nature and the Purusha or the Soul is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied (men). Chapter 8, Verse 5: 8.5 And whosoever, leaving the body, goes forth remembering Me alone, at the time of death, he attains My Being: there is no doubt about this. Chapter 8, Verse 6: 8.6 Whosoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), because of his constant thought of that being. Chapter 8, Verse 7: 8.7 Therefore at all times remember Me only and fight. With mind and intellect fixed (or absorbed) in Me, thou shalt doubtessly come to Me alone.
chunk_63.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 63

chunk_64.content: Chapter 8, Verse 8: 8.8 With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast by the method of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna. Chapter 8, Verse 9: 8.9 Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler (of the whole world), minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance. Chapter 8, Verse 10: 8.10 At the time of death, with unshaken mind, endowed with devotio, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person. Chapter 8, Verse 11: 8.11 That which is declared Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that desiring which celibacy is practised  that goal I will declare to thee in brief.
chunk_64.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 64

chunk_65.content:
Chapter 8, Verse 12: 8.12 Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart and fixed the life-breath in the head, engaged in the practice of concentration. Chapter 8, Verse 13: 8.13 Uttering the one-syllabled Om  the Brahman  and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains to the Supreme Goal. Chapter 8, Verse 14: 8.14 I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast Yogi who constantly and daily remembers Me (for a long time), not thinking of anything else (with a single mind or one-pointed mind), O Partha (Arjuna). Chapter 8, Verse 15: 8.15 Having attained Me these great souls do not again take birth (here) which is the place of pain 
and is non-eternal: they have reached the highest perfection (liberation). Chapter 8, Verse 16: 8.16 (All) the worlds including the world of Brahma are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rirth.
chunk_65.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 65

chunk_66.content: Chapter 8, Verse 17: 8.17 Those people who know the day of Brahma which is of a duration of a thousand Yugas (ages) and the night which is also of a thousand Yugas duration, they know day and night. Chapter 8, Verse 18: 8.18 From the Unmanifested all the manifested (worlds) proceed at the coming of the 'day'; at the coming of the 'night' they dissolve verily into ï1thatï1 alone which is called the Unmanifested. Chapter 8, Verse 19: 8.19 This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, is dissolved, helplessly, O Arjuna (into the Unmanifested) at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day. Chapter 8, Verse 20: 8.20 But verily there exists, higher than this Unmanifested, another unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed when all beings are destroyed. Chapter 8, Verse 21: 8.21 What is called the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That they say is the highest goal. They who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My highest abode (place or state).
chunk_66.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 66

chunk_67.content: Chapter 8, Verse 22: 8.22 That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded. Chapter 8, Verse 23: 8.23 Now I will tell thee, O chief of Bharatas, the times departing at which the Yogis will return or not return. Chapter 8, Verse 24: 8.24 Fire, light daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice)  departing then (by these) men who know Brahman go to Brahman. Chapter 8, Verse 25: 8.25 Attaining to the lunar light by smoke, night time, the dark fortnight also, the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the Yogi returns. Chapter 8, Verse 26: 8.26 The bright and the dark paths of the world are verily thought to be eternal; by the one (the bright path) a man goes not to return and by the other (the dark path) he returns.
chunk_67.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 67

chunk_68.content: Chapter 8, Verse 27: 8.27 Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no Yogi is deluded; therefore at all times be steadfast in Yoga. Chapter 8, Verse 28: 8.28 Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts  beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme Primeval (first or ancient) Abode. Chapter 9, Verse 1: 9.1 The Blessed Lord said  I shall now declare to thee who does not cavil, the greatest secret, the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this thou shalt be free evil. Chapter 9, Verse 2: 9.2 This is the kingl science, the kingly secret, the supreme purifier, realisable by direct intuitional knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable. Chapter 9, Verse 3: 9.3 Those who have no faith in this Dharma (knowledge of the Self), O Parantapa (Arjuna), return to the path of this world of death without attaining Me.
chunk_68.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 68

chunk_69.content: Chapter 9, Verse 4: 9.4 All this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist in Me, but I do not dwell in them. Chapter 9, Verse 5: 9.5 Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold My divine Yoga, supporting all beings, but not dwelling in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings. Chapter 9, Verse 6: 9.6 As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, rests always in the ether, even so, know thou that all beings rest in Me. Chapter 9, Verse 7: 9.7 All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of (the next) Kalpa. Chapter 9, Verse 8: 9.8 Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless by the force of the Nature.
chunk_69.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 69

chunk_70.content: Chapter 9, Verse 9: 9.9 These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting like one indifferent, unattached to those acts. Chapter 9, Verse 10: 9.10 Under Me as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; because of this, O Arjuna, the world revolves. Chapter 9, Verse 11: 9.11 Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of (all) beings. Chapter 9, Verse 12: 9.12 Of vain hopes, of vain actions, of vain knowledge and senseless, they verily are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings. Chapter 9, Verse 13: 9.13 But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single mind (with the mind devoted to nothing else), knowing Me as the imperishable source of beings.
chunk_70.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 70

chunk_71.content:
Chapter 9, Verse 14: 9.14 Always glorifying Me, striving,firm in vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with devotion always steadfast. Chapter 9, Verse 15: 9.15 Others also sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice worship Me, the All-faced, as one, as distinct, and as manifold. Chapter 9, Verse 16: 9.16 I am the Kratu; I am the Yajna; I am the offering (food) to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all the plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the Ghee or the melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation. Chapter 9, Verse 17: 9.17 I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions and the 
grandfather; the (one) thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik-, the Sama-and the Yajur-Vedas.
chunk_71.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 71

chunk_72.content: Chapter 9, Verse 18: 9.18 I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house and the seed which is imperishable. Chapter 9, Verse 19: 9.19 (As the sun) I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna. Chapter 9, Verse 20: 9.20 The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me by sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy in heavn the divine pleasures of the gods. Chapter 9, Verse 21: 9.21 They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the ï1threeï1 (Vedas) and desiring (objects of) desires, they attain to the state of going and returning.
chunk_72.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 72

chunk_73.content: Chapter 9, Verse 22: 9.22 For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, for those ever-united, I secure what is not already possessed and preserve what they already possess. Chapter 9, Verse 23: 9.23 Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, b the wrong method. Chapter 9, Verse 24: 9.24 (For) I alone am the enjoyer and also the Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in essence (in reality), and hence they fall (return to this mortal world). Chapter 9, Verse 25: 9.25 The worshippers of the gods go to them; to the manes go the ancestor-worshippers; to the deities who preside over the elements go their worshippers; but My devotees come to Me. Chapter 9, Verse 26: 9.26 Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit or a little water  that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
chunk_73.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 73

chunk_74.content: Chapter 9, Verse 27: 9.27 Whatever thou doest, whatever thou eatest, whatever thou offerest in sacrifice, whatever thou givest, whatever thou practisest as austerity, O Arjuna, do it as an offering unto Me. Chapter 9, Verse 28: 9.28 Thus shalt thou be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, thou shalt come unto Me. Chapter 9, Verse 29: 9.29 The same am I to all beings; to Me there is none hateful or dear; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I am also in them. Chapter 9, Verse 30: 9.30 Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to none else, he too should indeed by regarded as righteous for he has rightly resolved. Chapter 9, Verse 31: 9.31 Soon he becomes righteous and attains to eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.
chunk_74.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 74

chunk_75.content: Chapter 9, Verse 32: 9.32 For, taking refuge in Me, they also who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth  women, Vaisyas as well as Sudras  attain the Supreme Goal. Chapter 9, Verse 33: 9.33 How much more (easily) then the hold Brahmins and devoted royal saints (attain the goal); having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me. Chapter 9, Verse 34: 9.34 Fix thy mind on Me; by devoted to Me; sacrifice unto Me; bow down to Me; having thus united thy whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, thou shalt come unto Me. Chapter 10, Verse 1: 10.1 The Blessed Lord said  Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to thee who who art beloved, for thy welfare. Chapter 10, Verse 2: 10.2 Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for in every way I am the source of all the gods and the great sages.
chunk_75.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 75

chunk_76.content: Chapter 10, Verse 3: 10.3 He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he, among mortals, is undeluded and he is liberated from all sins. Chapter 10, Verse 4: 10.4 Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear and also fearlessness. Chapter 10, Verse 5: 10.5 Non-injury, eanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, ill-fame  (these) different kinds of alities of beings arise from Me alone. Chapter 10, Verse 6: 10.6 The seven great sages, the ancient four and also the Manus, possessed of powers like Me (on account of their minds being fixed on Me), were born of (My) mind; from them are these creatures born in this world. Chapter 10, Verse 7: 10.7 He who in truth knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and (this) Yoga-power of Mine becomes established in the unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.
chunk_76.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 76

chunk_77.content: Chapter 10, Verse 8: 10.8 I am the source of all; from Me everything evolves; understanding thus, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship Me. Chapter 10, Verse 9: 10.9 With their mind and their life wholly absorbed in Me, enlightening each other and ever speaking of Me, they are satisfied and delighted. Chapter 10, Verse 10: 10.10 To them who are ever steadfast, worshipping Me with love, I give the Yoga of discrimination by which they come to Me. Chapter 10, Verse 11: 10.11 Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their Self, destroy the darkness born of ignorance by the luminous lamp of knowledge. Chapter 10, Verse 12: 10.12 Arjuna said  Thou art the Supreme Brahman, the supreme abode (or the supreme light), the supreme purifier, eternal, divine Person, the primeval God, unborn andn omnipresent.
chunk_77.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 77

chunk_78.content:
Chapter 10, Verse 13: 10.13 All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself sayest so to me. Chapter 10, Verse 14: 10.14 I believe all this that Thou sayest to me to be true, O Krishna; verily, O blessed Lord! neither the gods nor the demons know Thy manifestation (origin). Chapter 10, Verse 15: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka Chapter 10, Verse 16: 10.16 Thou shouldst indeed tell, without reserve, of Thy divine glories by which Thou existest, pervading all these worlds. (None else can do so.) Chapter 10, Verse 17: 10.17 How shall I, ever meditating, know Thee, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed 
Lord, art Thou to be thought of by me?
chunk_78.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 78

chunk_79.content: Chapter 10, Verse 18: 10.18 Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of Thy Yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of Thy life-giving and nectar-like speech. Chapter 10, Verse 19: 10.19 The Blessed Lord said  Very well! Now I will declare to thee My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description. Chapter 10, Verse 20: 10.20 I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle and also the end of all beings. Chapter 10, Verse 21: 10.21 Among the (twelve) Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; I am Marichi among the (seven or forty-nine) Maruts; among stars the moon am I. Chapter 10, Verse 22: 10.22 Among the Vedas I am the Sama-Veda; I am Vasava among the gods; among the senses I am the mind; and I am intelligence among living beings.
chunk_79.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 79

chunk_80.content:
Chapter 10, Verse 23: 10.23 And, among the Rudras I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus I am Pavaka (fire); and among the (seven) mountains I am the Meru. Chapter 10, Verse 24: 10.24 And, among the household priests (of kings), O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals I am Skana; among lakes I am the ocean.
' Chapter 10, Verse 25: 10.25 Among the great sages I am Bhrigu; among words I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things I am the Himalayas. Chapter 10, Verse 26: 10.26 Among all the trees ( I am) the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among Gandharvas, Chitraratha; among the perfected, the sage Kapila.
chunk_80.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 80

chunk_81.content: Chapter 10, Verse 27: 10.27 Know Me as Ucchaisravas born of nectar, among horses; among lordly elephants (I am) the Airavata; and, among men, the king. Chapter 10, Verse 28: 10.28 Among weapons I am the thunderbolt; among cows I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents I am Vasuki. Chapter 10, Verse 29: 10.29 I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes I am; I am Yama among the governors. Chapter 10, Verse 30: 10.30 And, I am Prahlada among the demons, among the reckoners I am time; among beasts I am the lion, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds. Chapter 10, Verse 31: 10.31 Among the purifiers (or the speeders) I am the wind; Rama among the warriors am I; among the fishes I am the shark; among the streams I am the Ganga.
chunk_81.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 81

chunk_82.content:
Chapter 10, Verse 32: 10.32 Among creations I am the beginning, the middle and also the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists. Chapter 10, Verse 33: 10.33 Among the letters of the alphabets, the letter 'A' I am and the dual among the compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible or everlasting time; I am the dispenser (of the fruits of actions) having 
faces in all directions. Chapter 10, Verse 34: 10.34 And I am the all-devouring Death, and the prosperity of those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine alities (I am) fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness and forgiveness. Chapter 10, Verse 35: 10.35 Among the hymns also I am the Brihatsaman; among metres Gayatri am I; among the montsh I am the Margasirsha; among the seasons (I am) the flowery season.
chunk_82.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 82

chunk_83.content: Chapter 10, Verse 36: 10.36 I am the gambling of the fraudulent; I am the splendour of the splendid; I am victory; I am determination (of those who are determined); I am the goodness of the good. Chapter 10, Verse 37: 10.37 Among the Vrishnis I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas I am Arjuna; among the sages I am Vyasa; among the Poets I am Usanas, the poet. Chapter 10, Verse 38: 10.38 Of those who punish, I am the sceptre; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and also among secrets, I am silence; knowledge among knowers I am. Chapter 10, Verse 39: 10.39 And whatever is the seed of all beings, that also am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, whether moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me. Chapter 10, Verse 40: 10.40 There is no end to My divine gloreis, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glories.
chunk_83.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 83

chunk_84.content: Chapter 10, Verse 41: 10.41 Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous or powerful, that know thou to be a manifestation of a part of My splendour. Chapter 10, Verse 42: 10.42 But, of what avail to thee is the knowledge of all these details, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world by one part of Myself. Chapter 11, Verse 1: 11.1 Arjuna said  By this word (explanation) of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion is gone. Chapter 11, Verse 2: 11.2 The origin and the destruction of beings verily have been heard by me in detail from Thee, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Thy inexhaustible greatness. Chapter 11, Verse 3: 11.3 (Now) O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to see Thy divine form.
chunk_84.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 84

chunk_85.content: Chapter 11, Verse 4: 11.4 If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogins, show me Thy imperishable Self. Chapter 11, Verse 5: 11.5 The Blessed Lord said  Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colours and shapes. Chapter 11, Verse 6: 11.6 Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins and also the Maruts; behold many wonders never seen before, O Arjuna. Chapter 11, Verse 7: 11.7 Now behold, O Arjuna, in this, My body, the whole universe centred in one  including the moving and the unmoving  and whatever else thou desirest to see. Chapter 11, Verse 8: 11.8 But thou art not able to behold Me with these thine own eyes; I give thee the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.
chunk_85.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 85

chunk_86.content: Chapter 11, Verse 9: 11.9 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, hari (Krishna), showed to Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.
