Chapter 11, Verse 10: 11.10 With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wonderful sights, with numerous divine ornaments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted (such a form He showed). Chapter 11, Verse 11: 11.11 Wearing divine garlands (necklaces) and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent (Being) endless with faces on all sides. Chapter 11, Verse 12: 11.12 If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out at once (simultaneously) in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty Being (great Soul). Chapter 11, Verse 13: 11.13 There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the whole universe resting in one, with its many groups.
chunk_86.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 86

chunk_87.content:
Chapter 11, Verse 14: 11.14 Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and with his hair standing on end, bowed down his head to the God and spoke with joined palms. Chapter 11, Verse 15: 11.15 Arjuna said  I see all the gods, O God, in Thy body, and (also) hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma, the Lord, seated on the lotus, all the sages and the celestial serpents. Chapter 11, Verse 16: 11.16 I see Thee of boundless form on every side with many arms, stomachs, mouths and eyes: neither the end nor the middle nor also the beginning do I see, O Lord of the universe, O Cosmic Form. Chapter 11, Verse 17: 11.17 I see Thee with the diadem, the club and the discus, a mass of radiance shining 
everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all round like burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.
chunk_87.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 87

chunk_88.content: Chapter 11, Verse 18: 11.18 Thou art the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy to be known. Thou art the great treasure-house of this universe; Thou art the imperishable protector of the eternal Dhrama; Thou art the Primal Person, I deem. Chapter 11, Verse 19: 11.19 I see Thee without beginning, middle or end, infinite in power, of endless arms, the sun and the moon being Thy eyes, the burning fire Thy mouth, heating the whole universe with Thy radiance. Chapter 11, Verse 20: 11.20 This space between the earth and the heaven and all the arters are filled by Thee alone; having seen this, Thy wonderful and teriible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being. Chapter 11, Verse 21: 11.21 Verily, into Thee enter these hosts of gods; some extol Thee in fear with joined palms; saying 'may it be well', bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with hymns complete.
chunk_88.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 88

chunk_89.content: Chapter 11, Verse 22: 11.22 The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the manes and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons and the perfected ones, are all looking at Thee, in great amazement. Chapter 11, Verse 23: 11.23 Having seen Thy immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed, with many arms, thighs and feet, with many stomachs and fearful with many teeth  the worlds are terrified and so am I. Chapter 11, Verse 24: 11.24 On seeing Thee (the Cosmic Form) touching the sky, shining in many colours, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu. Chapter 11, Verse 25: 11.25 Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth (blazing) like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four arters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.
chunk_89.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 89

chunk_90.content: Chapter 11, Verse 26: 11.26 All the sons of Dhritarashtra, with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona and Karna, with the chief among our warriors. Chapter 11, Verse 27: 11.27 Some hurriedly enter Thy mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found sticking in the gaps between the teeth with their heads crushed to powder. Chapter 11, Verse 28: 11.28 Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, even so these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths. Chapter 11, Verse 29: 11.29 As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire for (their own) destruction, so also these creatures hurriedly rush into Thy mouths for (their own) destruction. Chapter 11, Verse 30: 11.30 Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, are burning, O Vishnu!
chunk_90.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 90

chunk_91.content: Chapter 11, Verse 31: 11.31 Tell me, who Thou art, so fierce of form. Salutations to Thee, O God Supreme: have mercy. I desire to know Thee, the original Being. I know not indeed Thy working. Chapter 11, Verse 32: 11.32 The Blessed Lord said  I am the full-grown world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without thee, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies shall live. Chapter 11, Verse 33: 11.33 Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Coner the enemies and enjoy the unrivalled kingdom. Verily by Me have they been already slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna. Chapter 11, Verse 34: 11.34 Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna and other brave warriors  these are already slain by Me: do thou kill; be not distressed with fear; fight and thou shalt coner thy enemies in battle. Chapter 11, Verse 35: 11.35 Sanjaya said  Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrating himself, again addressed Krishna, in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.
chunk_91.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 91

chunk_92.content: Chapter 11, Verse 36: 11.36 Arjuna said  It is meet, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Thy praise; demons fly in fear to all arters and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to Thee. Chapter 11, Verse 37: 11.37 And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater (than all else), the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being and That which is the supreme (that which is beyond the Being and the non-being). Chapter 11, Verse 38: 11.38 Thou art the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable and the supreme Abode. By Thee is the universe pervaded, O Being of infinite forms. Chapter 11, Verse 39: 11.39 Thou art Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. Salutations, salutations unto Thee, a thousand times, and again salutations, salutations unto Thee.
chunk_92.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 92

chunk_93.content: Chapter 11, Verse 40: 11.40 Salutations to Thee, in front and behind! Salutations to Thee on every side! O All!! Thou infinite in power and prowess, pervadest all; wherefore Thou art all. Chapter 11, Verse 41: 11.41 Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing Thee as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding Thee merely as a friend, unknowing of this, Thy greatness. Chapter 11, Verse 42: 11.42 In whatever way I may have insulted Thee for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting or at meals, when alone (with Thee), O Krishna, or in company  that I implore Thee, immeasurable one, to forgive. Chapter 11, Verse 43: 11.43 Thou art the Father of this world, moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world, Thou, the greatest Guru; (for) none there exists who is eal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unealled power?
chunk_93.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 93

chunk_94.content:
Chapter 11, Verse 44: 11.44 Therefore, bowing down, prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his (dear) friend, a lover his beloved, even so shouldst Thou 
forgive me, O God. Chapter 11, Verse 45: 11.45 I am delighted, having seen what has never been seen before; and yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that (previous) form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe. Chapter 11, Verse 46: 11.46 I desire to see Thee as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Thy former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Form (Being). Chapter 11, Verse 47: 11.47 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to thee by Me by My own Yogic power; full of splendour, primeval, and infinite, this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than thyself.
chunk_94.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 94

chunk_95.content: Chapter 11, Verse 48: 11.48 Neither by the study of the Vedas and sacrifices, nor by gifts nor by rituals nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than thyself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna). Chapter 11, Verse 49: 11.49 Be not afraid, nor bewildered on seeing such a teriible form of Mine as this; with thy fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine. Chapter 11, Verse 50: 11.50 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form and the great Soul (Krishna), assuming His gentle form, consoled him (Arjuna) who was terrified. Chapter 11, Verse 51: 11.51 Arjuna said  Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and am restored to my own nature. Chapter 11, Verse 52: 11.52 The Blessed Lord said  Very hard indeed it is to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen. Even the gods are ever longing to behold it.
chunk_95.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 95

chunk_96.content: Chapter 11, Verse 53: 11.53 Neither by the Vedas nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me (so easily). Chapter 11, Verse 54: 11.54 But by single-minded devotion can I, of this Form, be known and seen in reality and also entered into, O Arjuna. Chapter 11, Verse 55: 11.55 He who does all actions for Me, who looks upon Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears enmity towards no creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna. Chapter 12, Verse 1: 12.1 Arjuna said  Those devotees who, ever steadfast, thus worship Thee and those also who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested  which of them are better versed in Yoga? Chapter 12, Verse 2: 12.2 The Blessed Lord said  Those who, fixing their mind on Me, worship Me, ever steadfast and endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga in My opinion.
chunk_96.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 96

chunk_97.content: Chapter 12, Verse 3: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka Chapter 12, Verse 4: 12.4 Having restrained all the senses, even-minded everywhere, intent on the welfare of all beings  verily they also come unto Me. Chapter 12, Verse 5: 12.5 Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested; for the goal; the unmanifested, is very hard for the embodied to reach. Chapter 12, Verse 6: 12.6 But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme gaol, meditating on Me with single-minded Yoga. Chapter 12, Verse 7: 12.7 To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I become ere long the saviour out of the ocean of Samsara. Chapter 12, Verse 8: 12.8 Fix thy mind in Me only, thy intellect in Me, (then) thou shalt no doubt live in Me alone hereafter.
chunk_97.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 97

chunk_98.content: Chapter 12, Verse 9: 12.9 If thou art unable to fix thy mind steadily on Me, then by the Yoga of constant practice do thou seek to reach Me, O Arjuna. Chapter 12, Verse 10: 12.10 If thou art unable to practise even this Abhyasa Yoga, be thou intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, thou shalt attain perfection. Chapter 12, Verse 11: 12.11 If thou art unable to do even this, then, resorting to union with Me, renounce the fruits of all actions with the self controlled. Chapter 12, Verse 12: 12.12 Better indeed is knowledge than practice; than knowledge meditation is better; than meditation the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation. Chapter 12, Verse 13: 12.13 He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who is free from attachment and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving.
chunk_98.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 98

chunk_99.content: Chapter 12, Verse 14: 12.14 Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessed of firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devtoee, is dear to Me. Chapter 12, Verse 15: 12.15 He by whom the world is not agitated and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear and anxiety  he is dear to Me. Chapter 12, Verse 16: 12.16 He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings or commencements  he who is (thus) devoted to Me, is dear to Me. Chapter 12, Verse 17: 12.17 He who neither rejoices, nor hates, nor grieves, nor desires, renouncing good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me. Chapter 12, Verse 18: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
chunk_99.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 99

chunk_100.content: Chapter 12, Verse 19: 12.19 He to whom censure and praise are eal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion  that man is dear to Me. Chapter 12, Verse 20: 12.20 They verily who follow this immortal Dharma (law or doctrine) as described above, endowed with faith, regarding Me as their supreme goal, they, the devotees, are exceedingly dear to Me. Chapter 13, Verse 1: 13.1 Arjuna said  I wish to learn about Nature (matter) and the Spirit (soul), the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and that which ought to be known, O Kesava. Chapter 13, Verse 2: 13.2 The Blessed Lord said  This body, O Arjuna, is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field, by those who know of them. Chapter 13, Verse 3: 13.3 Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be ï1the ï1 knowledge.
chunk_100.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 100

chunk_101.content: Chapter 13, Verse 4: 13.4 What the field is and of what nature, what are its modifications and whence it is and also who He is and what His powers are  hear all that from Me in brief. Chapter 13, Verse 5: 13.5 Sages have sung in many ways, in various distinctive chants and also in the suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive. Chapter 13, Verse 6: 13.6 The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses. Chapter 13, Verse 7: 13.7 Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (the body), intelligence, fortitude  the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications. Chapter 13, Verse 8: 13.8 Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service of the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
chunk_101.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 101

chunk_102.content: Chapter 13, Verse 9: 13.9 Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perception of (or reflection on) the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness and pain. Chapter 13, Verse 10: 13.10 Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home and the rest, and constant even-mindedness on the attainment of the desirable and the undesirable. Chapter 13, Verse 11: 13.11 Unswerving devotion unto Me by the Yoga of non-separation, resort to solitary places, distaste for the society of men. Chapter 13, Verse 12: 13.12 Constancy in Self-knowledge, perception of the end of true knowledge  this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance. Chapter 13, Verse 13: 13.13 I will declare that which has to be known, knowing which one attains to immortality, the beginningless supreme Brahman, called neither being nor non-being.
chunk_102.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 102

chunk_103.content: Chapter 13, Verse 14: 13.14 With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds enveloping all. Chapter 13, Verse 15: 13.15 Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without the senses; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of alities, yet their experiencer. Chapter 13, Verse 16: 13.16 Without and within (all) beings the unmoving and also the moving; because of Its subtlety, unknowable; and near and far away is That. Chapter 13, Verse 17: 13.17 And undivided, yet It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of being; It devours and It generates. Chapter 13, Verse 18: 13.18 That, the Light of all lights, is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
chunk_103.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 103

chunk_104.content: Chapter 13, Verse 19: 13.19 Thus the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My Being. Chapter 13, Verse 20: 13.20 Know thou that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless; and know also that all modifications and alities are born of Nature. Chapter 13, Verse 21: 13.21 In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the cause. Chapter 13, Verse 22: 13.22 The soul seated in Nature experiences the alities born of Nature; attachment to the alities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs. Chapter 13, Verse 23: 13.23 The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the spectator, the permitter, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord and the Supreme Self.
chunk_104.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 104

chunk_105.content: Chapter 13, Verse 24: 13.24 He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with the alities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not born again. Chapter 13, Verse 25: 13.25 Some by meditation behold the Self in the self by the self, others by the Yoga of knowledge, and still others by the Yoga of action. Chapter 13, Verse 26: 13.26 Others also, not knowing thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the Supreme refuge. Chapter 13, Verse 27: 13.27 Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union between the field and its knower. Chapter 13, Verse 28: 13.28 He sees, who sees the Supreme Lord, existing eally in all beings, the unperishing within the perishing.
chunk_105.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 105

chunk_106.content: Chapter 13, Verse 29: 13.29 Because he who sees the same Lord eally dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; he goes to the highest goal. Chapter 13, Verse 30: 13.30 He sees, who sees that all actions are performed by Nature alone and that the Self is actionless. Chapter 13, Verse 31: 13.31 When a man sees the whole variety of beings as resting in the One, and spreading forth from That alone, he then becomes Brahman. Chapter 13, Verse 32: 13.32 Being without beginning and being devoid of (any) alities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted. Chapter 13, Verse 33: 13.33 As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, because of its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted.
chunk_106.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 106

chunk_107.content:
Chapter 13, Verse 34: 13.34 Just as the one sun illumines the whole world, so also the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) 
illumines the whole field, O Arjuna. Chapter 13, Verse 35: 13.35 They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower and also the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme. Chapter 14, Verse 1: 14.1 The Blessed Lord said  I will again declare (to thee) that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to the supreme perfection after this life. Chapter 14, Verse 2: 14.2 They who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained to unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor are they disturbed at the time of dissolution. Chapter 14, Verse 3: 14.3 My womb is the great Brahma; in that I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.
chunk_107.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 107

chunk_108.content: Chapter 14, Verse 4: 14.4 Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb and I am the seed-giving father. Chapter 14, Verse 5: 14.5 Purity, passion and inertia  these alities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body, the embodied, the indestructible. Chapter 14, Verse 6: 14.6 Of these, Sattva, which from its stainlessness is luminous and healthy, binds by attachment to happiness and by attachment to knowledge, O sinless one. Chapter 14, Verse 7: 14.7 Know thou Rajas to be of the nature of passion, the source of thirst (for sensual enjoyment) and attachment; it binds fast, O Arjuna, the embodied one by attachment to action. Chapter 14, Verse 8: 14.8 But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, by heedlessness, indolence and sleep.
chunk_108.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 108

chunk_109.content: Chapter 14, Verse 9: 14.9 Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas verily shrouding knowledge attaches to heedlessness. Chapter 14, Verse 10: 14.10 Now Sattva arises (prevails), O Arjuna, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; nor Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and now Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas. Chapter 14, Verse 11: 14.11 When through every gate (sense) in this body, the wisdom-light shines, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant. Chapter 14, Verse 12: 14.12 Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, longing  these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna. Chapter 14, Verse 13: 14.13 Darkness, inertness, heedlessness and delusion  these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.
chunk_109.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 109

chunk_110.content: Chapter 14, Verse 14: 14.14 If the embodied one meets with death when Sattva is predominant, then he attains to the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest. Chapter 14, Verse 15: 14.15 Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the senseless. Chapter 14, Verse 16: 14.16 The fruit of good action, they say, is Sattvic and pure, verily the fruit of Rajas is pain, and ignorance is the fruit of Tamas. Chapter 14, Verse 17: 14.17 From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance. Chapter 14, Verse 18: 14.18 Those who are seated in Sattva go upwards; the Rajasic dwell in the middle; and the Tamasic, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, go downwards.
chunk_110.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 110

chunk_111.content: Chapter 14, Verse 19: 14.19 When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows That which is higher than they, he attains to My Being. Chapter 14, Verse 20: 14.20 The embodied one having crossed beyond these three Gunas out of which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay and pain, and attains to immortality. Chapter 14, Verse 21: 14.21 Arjuna said  What are the marks of him who has transcended the three alities, O Lord? What is his conduct and how does he go beyond these three alities? Chapter 14, Verse 22: 14.22 The Blessed Lord said  When light, activity and delusion are present, he hates them not, nor does he long for them when they are absent. Chapter 14, Verse 23: 14.23 He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the alities, and who, knowing that the alities are active, is self-centred and moves not.
chunk_111.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 111

chunk_112.content: Chapter 14, Verse 24: 14.24 Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, stone and gold are alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are as one. Chapter 14, Verse 25: 14.25 Who is the same in honour and dishonour, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings  he is said to have transcended the alities. Chapter 14, Verse 26: 14.26 And he who serves Me with unswerving devotion, he, crossing beyond the alities, is fit for becoming Brahman. Chapter 14, Verse 27: 14.27 For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal and the immutable, of everlasting Dharma and of absolute bliss. Chapter 15, Verse 1: 15.1 The Blessed Lord said  They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree having its root above and branches below, whose leaves are the metres or hymns: he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.
chunk_112.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 112

chunk_113.content: Chapter 15, Verse 2: 15.2 Below and above spread its branches, nourished by the Gunas; sense-objects are its buds; and below, in the world of men, stretch forth the roots, originating action. Chapter 15, Verse 3: 15.3 Its form is not perceived here as such, neither its end nor its origin, nor its foundation nor resting place: having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment. Chapter 15, Verse 4: 15.4 Then That goal should be sought for, whither having gone none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha Whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy. Chapter 15, Verse 5: 15.5 Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, the undeluded reach the eternal goal. Chapter 15, Verse 6: 15.6 Neither doth the sun illumine there nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone thither they return not; that is My supreme abode.
chunk_113.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 113

chunk_114.content: Chapter 15, Verse 7: 15.7 An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to (itself) the (five) senses with the mind for the sixth, abiding in Nature. Chapter 15, Verse 8: 15.8 When the Lord (as the individual soul) obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these and goes (with them) as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.). Chapter 15, Verse 9: 15.9 Presiding over the ear, the eye, touch, taste and smell, as well as the mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses. Chapter 15, Verse 10: 15.10 The deluded do not see Him Who departs, stays and enjoys; but they who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him. Chapter 15, Verse 11: 15.11 The Yogins striving (for perfection) behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, see Him not.
chunk_114.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 114

chunk_115.content:
Chapter 15, Verse 12: 15.12 That light which residing in the sun illumines the whole world, that which is in the moon and in the fire  know that light to be Mine. Chapter 15, Verse 13: 15.13 Permeating the earth I support all beings by (My) energy; and having become the watery moon I nourish all herbs. Chapter 15, Verse 14: 15.14 Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the body of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food. Chapter 15, Verse 15: 15.15 And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me are memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas am I. Chapter 15, Verse 16: 15.16 Two Purushas there are in this world, the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are 
the perishable and the Kutastha  the unchanging  is called the imperishable.
chunk_115.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 115

chunk_116.content: Chapter 15, Verse 17: 15.17 But distinct is the Supreme Purusha called the highest Self, the indestructible Lord Who, pervading the three worlds, sustains them. Chapter 15, Verse 18: 15.18 As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas. Chapter 15, Verse 19: 15.19 He who, undeluded, knows Me thus as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna. Chapter 15, Verse 20: 15.20 Thus, this most secret science has been taught by Me, O sinless one; on knowing this, a man becomes wise, and all his duties are accomplished, O Arjuna. Chapter 16, Verse 1: 16.1 The Blessed Lord said  Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and Yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity and straightforwardness.
chunk_116.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 116

chunk_117.content: Chapter 16, Verse 2: 16.2 Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion towards beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness. Chapter 16, Verse 3: 16.3 Vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride  these belong to the one born for a divine state, O Arjuna. Chapter 16, Verse 4: 16.4 Hypocrisy, arrogance and self-conceit, anger and also harshness and ignorance, belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha (Arjuna). Chapter 16, Verse 5: 16.5 The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demoniacal to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, thou art born with divine endowments. Chapter 16, Verse 6: 16.6 There are two types of beings in this world, the divine and the demoniacal; the divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the demoniacal.
chunk_117.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 117

chunk_118.content: Chapter 16, Verse 7: 16.7 The demoniacal know not what to do and what to refrain from; neither purity, nor right conduct nor truth is found in them. Chapter 16, Verse 8: 16.8 They say, "This universe is without truth, without (moral) basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust for its cause; what else?" Chapter 16, Verse 9: 16.9 Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds, come forth as the enemies of the world for its destruction. Chapter 16, Verse 10: 16.10 Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride and arrogance, holding evil ideas through delusion, they work with impure resolves. Chapter 16, Verse 11: 16.11 Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares ending only with death, regarding gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.
chunk_118.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 118

chunk_119.content: Chapter 16, Verse 12: 16.12 Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain by unlawful means hoards to wealth for sensual enjoyments. Chapter 16, Verse 13: 16.13 "This has been gained by me today; this desire of mine I shall fuffil; this is mine and this wealth also shall be mine in future." Chapter 16, Verse 14: 16.14 "That enemy has been slain by me; and others also I shall slay. I am the lord. I enjoy. I am perfect, powerful and happy." Chapter 16, Verse 15: 16.15 "I am rich and born in a noble family. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices. I shall give (charity). I shall rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance. Chapter 16, Verse 16: 16.16 Bewildered by many a fancy, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.
chunk_119.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 119

chunk_120.content: Chapter 16, Verse 17: 16.17 Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with the pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name out of ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances. Chapter 16, Verse 18: 16.18 Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in those of others. Chapter 16, Verse 19: 16.19 Those cruel haters, worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only. Chapter 16, Verse 20: 16.20 Entering into demoniacal wombs and deluded, birth after birth, not attaining Me, they thus fall, O Arjuna, into a condition still lower than that. Chapter 16, Verse 21: 16.21 Triple is the gate of this hell, destructive of the self  lust, anger and greed; therefore one should abandon these three.
chunk_120.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 120

chunk_121.content: Chapter 16, Verse 22: 16.22 A man who is liberated from these three gates to darkness, O Arjuna, practises what is good for him and thus goes to the Supreme Goal. Chapter 16, Verse 23: 16.23 He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, attains not perfection, nor happiness nor the Supreme Goal. Chapter 16, Verse 24: 16.24 Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act here in this world. Chapter 17, Verse 1: 17.1 Arjuna said  Those who, setting aside the ordinances of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith, what is their condition, O Krishna? Is is Sattva, Rajas or Tamas? Chapter 17, Verse 2: 17.2 The Blessed Lord said  Threefold is the faith of the embodied, which is inherent in their nature  the Sattvic (pure), the Rajasic (passionate) and the Tamasic (dark). Do thou hear of it.
chunk_121.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 121

chunk_122.content: Chapter 17, Verse 3: 17.3 The faith of each is in accordance with his nature, O Arjuna. The man consists of his faith; as a man's faith is, so is he. Chapter 17, Verse 4: 17.4 The Sattvic or the pure men worship the gods; the Rajasic or the passionate worship the Yakshas and the Rakshasas; the others (the Tamasic or the deluded people) worship the ghosts and the hosts of the nature-spirits. Chapter 17, Verse 5: 17.5 Those men who practise terrific austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, impelled by the force of lust and attachment. Chapter 17, Verse 6: 17.6 Senseless, torturing all the elements in the body and Me also, Who dwell in the body,  know thou these to be of demonical resolves. Chapter 17, Verse 7: 17.7 The food also which is dear to each is threefold, as also sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Hear thou the distinction of these.
chunk_122.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 122

chunk_123.content: Chapter 17, Verse 8: 17.8 The foods which increase life, purity, strength, health, joy and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savoury and oleaginous, substantial and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people. Chapter 17, Verse 9: 17.9 The foods that are bitter, sour, saline, excessively hot, pungent, dry and burning, are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief and disease. Chapter 17, Verse 10: 17.10 That which is state, tasteless, putrid, rotten, refuse and impure, is the food liked by the Tamasic. Chapter 17, Verse 11: 17.11 That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that to do so is a duty, is Sattvic or pure. Chapter 17, Verse 12: 17.12 The sacrifice which is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for ostentation, know thou that to be a Rajasic Yajna.
chunk_123.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 123

chunk_124.content: Chapter 17, Verse 13: 17.13 They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, which is devoid of Mantras, gifts and faith. Chapter 17, Verse 14: 17.14 Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers and the wise, purity, straightforwardness, celibacy and non-injury are called the austerities of the body. Chapter 17, Verse 15: 17.15 Speech which causes no excitement, truthful, pleasant and beneficial, the practice of the study of the Vedas, are called austerity of speech. Chapter 17, Verse 16: 17.16 Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, purity of nature  this is called mental austerity. Chapter 17, Verse 17: 17.17 This threefold austerity, practised by steadfast men, with the utmost faith, desiring no reward, they call Sattvic.
chunk_124.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 124

chunk_125.content: Chapter 17, Verse 18: 17.18 The austerity which is practised with the object of gaining good reception, honour and worship, and with hypocrisy, is here said to be Rajasic, unstable and transitory. Chapter 17, Verse 19: 17.19 That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be Tamasic. Chapter 17, Verse 20: 17.20 That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a fit place and time to a worthy person, that gift is held to be Sattvic. Chapter 17, Verse 21: 17.21 And, that gift which is given with a view to receive something in return, or looking for a reward, or reluctantly, is held to be Rajasic. Chapter 17, Verse 22: 17.22 The gift that is given at a wrong place and time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult is declared to be Tamasic.
chunk_125.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 125

chunk_126.content: Chapter 17, Verse 23: 17.23 "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that were created formerly, the Brahmanas, the Vedas and the sacrifices. Chapter 17, Verse 24: 17.24 Therefore, with the utterance of "Om" are the acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity as enjoined in the scriptures, always begun by the students of Brahman. Chapter 17, Verse 25: 17.25 Uttering ï1Tatï1, without aiming at the fruits, are the acts of sacrifice and austerity and the various acts of gifts performed by the seekers of liberation. Chapter 17, Verse 26: 17.26 The word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of reality and of goodness; and so also, O Arjuna, the word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of an auspicious act. Chapter 17, Verse 27: 17.27 Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity and gift, is also called 'Sat' and also action in connection with these (or for the sake of the Supreme) is called 'Sat'.
chunk_126.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 126

chunk_127.content: Chapter 17, Verse 28: 17.28 Whatever is sacrificed, given or performed, and whatever austerity is practised without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is naught here or hereafter (after death). Chapter 18, Verse 1: 18.1 Arjuna said  I desire to know severally, O mighty-armed, the essence or truth of renunciation, O Hrishikesa, as also of abandonment, O slayer of Kesi. Chapter 18, Verse 2: 18.2 The Blessed Lord said  The sages understand Sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions as Tyaga. Chapter 18, Verse 3: 18.3 Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as an evil; while others (declare) that acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be relinished. Chapter 18, Verse 4: 18.4 Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, verily, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.
chunk_127.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 127

chunk_128.content: Chapter 18, Verse 5: 18.5 Acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; sacrifice, gift and also austerity are the purifiers of the wise. Chapter 18, Verse 6: 18.6 But even these actions should be performed leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is My certain and best conviction. Chapter 18, Verse 7: 18.7 Verily the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same from delusion is declared to be Tamasic. Chapter 18, Verse 8: 18.8 He who abandons action on account of the fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by doing such Rajasic renunciation. Chapter 18, Verse 9: 18.9 Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as Sattvic (pure).
chunk_128.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 128

chunk_129.content: Chapter 18, Verse 10: 18.10 The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate a disagreeable work nor is he attached to an agreeable one. Chapter 18, Verse 11: 18.11 Verily, it is not possible for an embodied being to abandon actions entirely; but he who relinishes the rewards of actions is verily called a man of renunciation. Chapter 18, Verse 12: 18.12 The threefold fruit of action (evil, good and mixed) accrues after death to the non-abandoners, but never to the abandoners. Chapter 18, Verse 13: 18.13 Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes as declared in the Sankhya system for the accomplishment of all actions. Chapter 18, Verse 14: 18.14 The seat (body), the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various sorts, and the presiding deity, also, the fifth.
chunk_129.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 129

chunk_130.content:
Chapter 18, Verse 15: 18.15 Whatever action a man performs with his body, speech and mind  whether right or the reverse  these five are its causes. Chapter 18, Verse 16: 18.16 Now, such being the case, verily he who  owing to untrained understanding  looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence, sees not. Chapter 18, Verse 17: 18.17 He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted (by good or evil), 
though he slays these people, he slayeth not, nor is he bound (by the action). Chapter 18, Verse 18: 18.18 Knowledge, the knowable and the knower form the threefold impulse to action; the organ, the action and the agent form the threefold basis of action. Chapter 18, Verse 19: 18.19 Knowledge, action and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these also, hear duly.
chunk_130.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 130

chunk_131.content: Chapter 18, Verse 20: 18.20 That by which one sees the one indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in all the separate beings  know thou that knowledge to be Sattvic. Chapter 18, Verse 21: 18.21 But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as different from one another  know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic. Chapter 18, Verse 22: 18.22 But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without foundation in Truth, and trivial  that is declared to be Tamasic. Chapter 18, Verse 23: 18.23 An action which is ordained, which is free from attachment, and which is done without love or hatred by one who is not desirous of any reward  that action is declared to be Sattvic. Chapter 18, Verse 24: 18.24 But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfilment of desires or gain with egoism or with much effort  that is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).
chunk_131.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 131

chunk_132.content: Chapter 18, Verse 25: 18.25 That action which is undertaken from delusion, without a regard for the conseences, loss, injury and (one's own) ability  that is declared to be Tamasic (dark). Chapter 18, Verse 26: 18.26 An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is called Sattvic (pure). Chapter 18, Verse 27: 18.27 Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic (passionate). Chapter 18, Verse 28: 18.28 Unsteady, vulgar, unbending, cheating, malicious, lazy, desponding and procrastinating  such an agent is called Tamasic. Chapter 18, Verse 29: 18.29 Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.
chunk_132.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 132

chunk_133.content: Chapter 18, Verse 30: 18.30 The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what ought to be done and what ought not to be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation  that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna. Chapter 18, Verse 31: 18.31 That, by which one wrongly understands Dharma and Adharma and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate). Chapter 18, Verse 32: 18.32 That, which, enveloped in darkness, sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Tamasic (dark). Chapter 18, Verse 33: 18.33 The unwavering firmness by which, through Yoga, the functions of the mind, the life-force and the senses are restrained  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
chunk_133.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 133

chunk_134.content: Chapter 18, Verse 34: 18.34 But that, O Arjuna, by which, on account of attachment and desire for reward, one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures and earning of wealth  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate). Chapter 18, Verse 35: 18.35 That, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair and also conceit  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Tamasic. Chapter 18, Verse 36: 18.36 And now hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices by practice and surely comes to the end of pain. Chapter 18, Verse 37: 18.37 That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar  that happiness is declared to be Sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to Self-realisation. Chapter 18, Verse 38: 18.38 That happiness which arises from the contact of the sense-organs with the objects, which is at first like nectar, and in the end like poison  that is declared to be Rajasic.
chunk_134.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 134

chunk_135.content: Chapter 18, Verse 39: 18.39 That happiness which at first as well as in the seel deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence and heedlessness  that is declared to be Tamasic. Chapter 18, Verse 40: 18.40 There is no being on earth or again in heaven among the gods, that is liberated from the three alities born of Nature. Chapter 18, Verse 41: 18.41 Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas and Vaisyas, as also of Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the alities born of their own nature. Chapter 18, Verse 42: 18.42 Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness and also uprightness, knowledge, realisation and belief in God are the duties of the Brahmanas, born of (their own) nature. Chapter 18, Verse 43: 18.43 Prowess, splendour, firmness, dexterity and also not fleeing from battle, generosity and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of (their own) nature.
chunk_135.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 135

chunk_136.content: Chapter 18, Verse 44: 18.44 Agriculture, cattle-rearing and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of (their own) nature; and action consisting of service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of (their own) nature. Chapter 18, Verse 45: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water. Chapter 18, Verse 46: 18.46 He from Whom all the beings have evolved and by Whom all this is pervaded  worshipping Him with his own duty, man attains perfection. Chapter 18, Verse 47: 18.47 Better is one's own duty (though) destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin. Chapter 18, Verse 48: 18.48 One should not abandon, O Arjuna, the duty to which one is born, though faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, as fire by smoke.
chunk_136.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 136

chunk_137.content: Chapter 18, Verse 49: 18.49 He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled,  he by renunciation, attains the supreme state of freedom from action. Chapter 18, Verse 50: 18.50 Learn from Me in brief, O Arjuna, how he who has attained perfection reaches Brahman (the Eternal), that supreme state of knowledge. Chapter 18, Verse 51: 18.51 Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self by firmness, relinishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred. Chapter 18, Verse 52: 18.52 Dwelling in solitude, eating but little, with speech, body and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, resorting to dispassion. Chapter 18, Verse 53: 18.53 Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger and covetousness, and free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful,  he is fit for becoming Brahman.
chunk_137.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 137

chunk_138.content: Chapter 18, Verse 54: 18.54 Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires, the same to all beings, he obtains supreme devotion to Me. Chapter 18, Verse 55: 18.55 By devotion he knows Me in truth, what and who I am; then having known Me in truth, he forthwith enters into the Supreme. Chapter 18, Verse 56: 18.56 Doing all actions always having taken refuge in Me, by My grace he obtains the eternal indestructible state of being. Chapter 18, Verse 57: 18.57 Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, resorting to the Yoga of discrimination do thou ever fix thy mind on Me. Chapter 18, Verse 58: 18.58 Fixing thy mind on Me, thou shalt by My grace overcome all obstacles; but if from egoism thou wilt not hear Me, thou shalt perish.
chunk_138.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 138

chunk_139.content: Chapter 18, Verse 59: 18.59 If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest: "I will not fight", vain is this, thy resolve; Nature will compel thee. Chapter 18, Verse 60: 18.60 O Arjuna, bound by thy own Karma (action) born of thy own nature, that which from delusion thou wishest not to do, even that thou shalt do helplessly. Chapter 18, Verse 61: 18.61 The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings, by His illusive power, to revolve as if mounted on a machine. Chapter 18, Verse 62: 18.62 Fly unto Him for refuge with all thy being, O Arjuna; by His grace thou shalt obtain supreme peace (and) the eternal abode. Chapter 18, Verse 63: 18.63 Thus has wisdom, more secret than secrecy itself, been declared unto thee by Me; having reflected over it fully, then act as thou wishest.
chunk_139.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 139

chunk_140.content: Chapter 18, Verse 64: 18.64 Hear thou again My supreme word, most secret of all; because thou art dearly beloved of Me, I will tell thee what is good. Chapter 18, Verse 65: 18.65 Fix thy mind on Me, by devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. Thou shalt come even to Me; truly do I promise unto thee, (for) thou art dear to Me. Chapter 18, Verse 66: 18.66 Abandoning all duties, take refuge in Me alone: I will liberate thee from all sins; grieve not. Chapter 18, Verse 67: 18.67 This is never to be spoken by thee to one who is devoid of austerities or devotion, nor to one who does not render service or who does not desire to listen, nor to one who cavils at Me. Chapter 18, Verse 68: 18.68 He who with supreme devotion to Me will teach this supreme secret to My devotees, shall doubtlessly come to Me.
chunk_140.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 140

chunk_141.content: Chapter 18, Verse 69: 18.69 Nor is there any among men who does dearer service to Me, nor shall there be another on earth dearer to Me than he. Chapter 18, Verse 70: 18.70 And he who will study this sacred dialogue of ours, by him I shall have been worshipped by the sacrifice of wisdom,  such is My conviction. Chapter 18, Verse 71: 18.71 Also the man who hears this, full of faith and free from malice, he, too, liberated, shall attain to the happy worlds of those of righteous deeds. Chapter 18, Verse 72: 18.72 Has this been heard, O Arjuna, with one-pointed mind? Has the delusion of thy ignorance been destroyed, O Dhananjaya? Chapter 18, Verse 73: 18.73 Arjuna said  Destroyed is my delusion as I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Thy grace, O Krishna. I remain freed from doubts. I will act according to Thy word.
chunk_141.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 141

chunk_142.content: Chapter 18, Verse 74: 18.74 Sanjaya said  Thus I have heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and the high-souled Arjuna, which causes the hair to stand on end. Chapter 18, Verse 75: 18.75 Through the grace of Vyasa I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga direct from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it. Chapter 18, Verse 76: 18.76 O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again. Chapter 18, Verse 77: 18.77 And, remembering again and again, also that most wonderful form of Hari, great is my wonder, O King; and I rejoice again and again. Chapter 18, Verse 78: 18.78 Wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga; wherever is Arjuna, the wielder of the bow; there are prosperity, victory, happiness and firm policy; such is my conviction.
chunk_142.title: Bhagavad Gita - Chunk 142
